title: Understanding Momentum with a Sliding Ball
topic: Explaining the concept of momentum using a simple sliding ball scenario.

acts.narration: Imagine gently sliding a ball across a smooth floor. Why does it keep moving even after you stop pushing it? This is due to momentum.

visuals.content: A yellow circle representing a ball sliding smoothly from left to right across the screen on a flat surface

acts.purpose: Hook the audience with a relatable scenario and introduce the topic of momentum.

acts.narration: Momentum is a measure of the motion of an object and is dependent on two factors: mass and velocity.
acts.purpose: Introduce the concept of momentum and its dependence on mass and velocity.

acts.narration: The formula for momentum is p equals m multiplied by v, where p is momentum, m is mass, and v is velocity.
acts.purpose: Present and explain the mathematical representation of momentum.

acts.narration: Let's see an example. A ball of mass 2 kg sliding with a velocity of 3 m/s. Its momentum is 6 kg·m/s.

visuals.content: A purple circle representing a ball with an adjacent label showing mass = 2 kg and velocity = 3 m/s, then calculating the momentum as 6 kg·m/s

acts.purpose: Provide a concrete example to build intuition about how to calculate momentum.

acts.narration: Understanding momentum helps explain why objects in motion stay in motion and is fundamental in physics. It applies to everything from sports to car safety.

visuals.content: A sequence of simple shapes: a rectangle representing a car, a circle as a soccer ball, and a square as a box, all moving to illustrate motion

acts.purpose: Summarize the concept and connect it to real-world applications.

source_prompt: Explain momentum with a sliding ball
